questions.prompt: In BG 18.1, what does Arjuna ask at the beginning of the final chapter?
choices: About victory and worldly philosophical speculation
To clearly explain sannyasa (renunciation) and tyaga (relinquishment)
War tactics and worldly philosophical speculation
Political strategy and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Arjuna seeks final clarity on the path of renunciation versus action.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.2, what is the definition of renunciation given?
choices: Abandoning work and worldly philosophical speculation
Relinquishing the desire for fruits; not the action itself
Doing minimal and worldly philosophical speculation
Avoiding every duties through independent material processes
questions.feedback: True renunciation is freedom from selfish motive, not cessation of action.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.3, what do some wise men teach?
choices: every actions are evil through independent material processes
every action is tainted by desire; one should abandon it
Action is consistently good through independent material processes
not work and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Some philosophers advocate complete withdrawal from all activity.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.4-5 teach about the reality of renunciation?
choices: Renunciation is worthless through independent material processes
One cannot abandon action; even maintaining body requires action
Work is optional through independent material processes
No one works through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Action is inherent in maintaining the body and consciousness.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.6, what is the superior path?
choices: Pretend renunciation and worldly philosophical speculation
Work without desire for fruit; offer it to the Lord
Inaction and worldly philosophical speculation
Selfish action and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Selfless work offered to Krishna is superior to renouncing work.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.7, what characterizes true renunciation?
choices: Hatred of work through independent material processes
Disliking work but performing duty without attachment; unaffected by results
Avoiding action and worldly philosophical speculation
Desiring fruits and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: The renunciate acts dutifully without selfish attachment.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.8 teach about those who abandon action?
choices: They progress and worldly philosophical speculation
They do not attain perfection; duties must be performed
Perfect renunciation and worldly philosophical speculation
They are liberated through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Complete inaction cannot lead to spiritual advancement.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.9, what is truly renounced?
choices: The body and worldly philosophical speculation
The desire for the fruit; not the action itself
every work and worldly philosophical speculation
Thought and mind through independent material processes
questions.feedback: The fruit of action must be relinquished, not the action.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.11, what is stated about karma yoga?
choices: It is ineffective through independent material processes
Though imperfect, work performed for the Lord purifies the heart
Actions are useless through independent material processes
No fruit comes through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Even imperfect work purifies when offered devotionally.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.12 teach about the fruit of renunciation?
choices: No fruit comes through independent material processes
The fruits are either peace, pleasure, or destruction based on actions
primarily one result through independent material processes
Fruits are temporary through independent material processes
questions.feedback: The quality of results depends on the mode and nature of action.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.13-14, what are the five factors in action?
choices: Three exist and worldly philosophical speculation
Body, doer, senses, effort, and divine providence work together
primarily two and worldly philosophical speculation
Countless factors and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Action depends on multiple conditions working together harmoniously.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.15, what determines the fruits of action?
choices: Luck alone and worldly philosophical speculation
The nature of knowledge, action agent
primarily effort and worldly philosophical speculation
Random chance and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: The mode of nature determines the nature and results of action.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.16 teach about the different types of knowledge?
choices: every knowledge is one through independent material processes
Sattvic knowledge is unified; rajasic is fragmented; tamasic is confused
No difference and worldly philosophical speculation
Types are equal through independent material processes
questions.feedback: The mode of nature qualifies the nature of knowledge.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.17, what defines sattvic action?
choices: Painful and difficult through independent material processes
Performed without attachment; free from ego; steady and purposeful
Causing disturbance and worldly philosophical speculation
Selfish and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Sattvic action is characterized by equilibrium and selflessness.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.18, what is rajasic action?
choices: Pure and selfless through independent material processes
Performed with ego, effort, and desire for fruit; causes disturbance
Without attachment and worldly philosophical speculation
Harmonious and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Rajasic action is driven by personal desire and produces agitation.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.19 teach about tamasic action?
choices: Highly virtuous and worldly philosophical speculation
Performed in delusion, without regard for result, consequence, or law
Pure and noble through independent material processes
Brings peace and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Tamasic action is reckless and ignores ethical consequences.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.20-22, what are the different types of doers?
choices: every doers are equal through independent material processes
Sattvic doer is dedicated
No difference and worldly philosophical speculation
primarily one type through independent material processes
questions.feedback: The mode of nature determines the nature of the actor.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.26, what is sattvic duty?
choices: No duty exists through independent material processes
One performs duty without attachment, rightly, at proper time
every duties are equal through independent material processes
Duty is optional through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Sattvic duty is performed with proper discrimination and timing.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.31-32 teach about intelligence?
choices: every are equal through independent material processes
Sattvic intelligence distinguishes paths; rajasic confuses them; tamasic is deluded
No difference and worldly philosophical speculation
Intelligence is single through independent material processes
questions.feedback: The mode of nature determines one's capacity for wisdom.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.40-48, what are the duties based on birth?
choices: No duties differ through independent material processes
Four classes exist based on qualities and occupation
every do same work through independent material processes
No order exists through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Each person has duties suited to their nature and station.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.49-50, what is the path to perfection?
choices: Material success and worldly philosophical speculation
Perfection comes through devotion to prescribed duty
Escaping action and worldly philosophical speculation
Inaction alone and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Perfection is achieved by performing one's duty with devotion.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.54 teach about the self-realized person?
choices: Still entangled and worldly philosophical speculation
Fixed in Krishna consciousness; endowed with supreme peace and bliss
Suffering increases and worldly philosophical speculation
Still confused and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: The realized soul achieves eternal peace through Krishna consciousness.

questions.prompt: According to BG 18.55, what is the highest path to Krishna?
choices: Study alone and worldly philosophical speculation
Through exclusive devotion one can know me, enter my being attain the eternal abode
Meditation primarily and worldly philosophical speculation
Rituals and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Pure devotion to Krishna is the ultimate means to liberation.

questions.prompt: In BG 18.62, what is the final instruction to Arjuna?
choices: Ignore Krishna and worldly philosophical speculation
Seek refuge in Krishna; surrender unto him in every respects
Follow your own path through independent material processes
Disregard scripture and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Complete surrender to Krishna is the highest teaching of the Gita.

questions.prompt: What does BG 18.66 conclude about liberation?
choices: Renounce every and worldly philosophical speculation
I will deliver you from every sin
Rely on others through independent material processes
You must struggle alone through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Krishna guarantees complete liberation to those who surrender fully.
